content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice problem. I added in a note in the problem description to illustrate that the grid squares are fixed and not movable, as it was something not quite clear from the earlier description.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple game while admitting many solutions (array manipulation is pretty permissive), fast to code, interesting in shortest.

Nice puzzle. I think the statement would be clearer if you introduced the concept of grid formally : "A gold mining operation works on a mxn area containing a certain amount of gold. To make exploitation simple, the area is divided as a grid of squares of size kxk. Each day, the miner mines one of those kxk square completely, until the whole area has been mined. (In total, there will be (m/k)*(n/k) days of mining.)"

I think it is better, because it is clear that we divide the area in a grid, while in your statement, you have to combine the information that only kxk squares are mined, that they shouldn't overlap, that all the area should be mined, and that the area exactly fits those squares since m%k==n%k==0. Your constraints define a grid, so stating it is one from the get go would make it less convoluted.

Reading the statement for the first time, i was trying to understand if this was a backtracking problem where any square could be considered (even if "what is the maximum amount of gold in one day" makes no sense in that case).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I found it interesting and fun.

My result for Validator 2 is different from yours

Result:
32 (5 1 4, 1 5 2, 5 4 5)

My program:

m, n, k = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
s = [[0]*n for _ in range(m)]

def get(s,i,j):
    return s[i][j] if -1<i<len(s) and -1<j<len(s[0]) else 0

for i in range(m):
    p = 0
    for j,c in enumerate(input().split()):
        p += int(c)
        s[i][j] = (s[i-1][j] if i else 0) + p

res = 0
for i in range(m):
    for j in range(n):
        res = max(res, get(s,i,j) - get(s,i-k,j)-get(s,i,j-k)+get(s,i-k,j-k))

print(res)

BTW I think you can try some large inputs, time complexity for this problem should have the order of O(mn)
Anything wrong?

Just a little refinement:
"A gold mining operation works on a mxn area containing a certain amount of gold."

Here if the "of squares" is left  out, the "containing a certain amount of gold" should be left out, because they belongs together.

I would suggest for the first sentence:

"A gold mining operation works on a mxn area."

For a non native English speaker it would be more understandable:

A gold mining operation works on a mxn area of squares containing a certain amount of gold.
Each day it mines a kxk part of the area.

Input:
Next m lines: n space-separated integers indicating the amount of gold in a square

Constraints:
m % k == n % k == 0
(So the area can be covered with integer number of non overlapping kxk parts)
Please let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement :)
Thanks. Your sentences are indeed clearer.
Thanks. I made amendments. I think this clarifies things the most. Let me know if you disagree.
The mined squares should fit the whole area like a grid, so the square you're using isn't used.  Should I clarify that you only mine a total of (m/k)*(n/k) days?
Your right, I like your formulation better. Changed it to yours and removed the sentence in parentheses at the end. Thanks!
I don't see how this is necessary. It should be clear from the definition of a grid: "A pattern of regularly spaced horizontal and vertical lines." I don't know what you mean by movable.
This is because typically in such problems, the grid is a moving one, where you move your k by k square throughout the entire grid.
One last thing, in the second line in validator 1 (1 1 0 0) there is a space after the last 0. Depending on the language, this might makes it tricky to process.

I added a skip condition to my code and it works.

...
if (i+1)%k or (j+1)%k:continue
res = max(res, get(s,i,j) - get(s,i-k,j)-get(s,i,j-k)+get(s,i-k,j-k))
...

I strongly suggest you add more conditions or tips. 

If you mean the mining area can only be the one bounded by top-left block (x,x) and bottom-right block (x+k,-1y+k-1) where x is a multiple of k, you should indicate that.

And I think your solution is within the order of O(mnkk) which is clean but not the fastest in terms of time complexity, hope this helps!

Thanks. I clarified the statement. Let me know if you think it's unclear

And indeed your solution is faster, nice :)
